message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Clitoromegaly suggests congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). The laboratory studies show a low sodium, high potassium, and low bicarbonate, which are common in CAH. Hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone are used in the management of CAH. Estrogen replacement therapy and spironolactone therapy are not appropriate in this case. Dexamethasone therapy may be used in CAH, but hydrocortisone is preferred in the acute phase.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn girl has clitoromegaly, which suggests congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) and the laboratory findings also support this diagnosis. Hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone therapy are the treatment of choice for CAH. Estrogen replacement therapy and dexamethasone therapy are not indicated for this condition, and spironolactone therapy is not appropriate for a newborn.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clitoromegaly and laboratory findings suggest congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). Hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone therapy are the treatments of choice for CAH. Estrogen replacement therapy is not appropriate due to the risk of virilization. Dexamethasone therapy can be used for prenatal treatment of CAH, but not for postnatal treatment. Spironolactone is not used in the treatment of CAH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn girl has clitoromegaly, which suggests congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). The laboratory values show decreased sodium and increased potassium levels, which confirms the diagnosis of CAH. Hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone therapy is the appropriate treatment for CAH. Estrogen replacement therapy, dexamethasone therapy, and spironolactone therapy are not appropriate for this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of clitoromegaly suggests congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), which is confirmed by the laboratory studies showing electrolyte abnormalities. Hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone therapy is the mainstay of treatment for CAH. Estrogen replacement therapy is not appropriate for a newborn. Dexamethasone and spironolactone may be used for CAH but are not the initial therapy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Clitoromegaly suggests congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), which is confirmed by the electrolyte imbalance and laboratory values. Hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone therapy is the appropriate next step in the management of this patient. Estrogen replacement therapy, dexamethasone therapy, and spironolactone therapy are not appropriate for treating CAH.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Clitoromegaly suggests congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). The laboratory results show an elevated potassium level and low bicarbonate level, which are also suggestive of CAH. The most appropriate next step is hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone therapy. Estrogen replacement therapy is not indicated in newborns. Dexamethasone therapy is an alternative but not the first choice. Spironolactone therapy is not appropriate for newborns.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn has clitoromegaly, which suggests congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). The laboratory studies show hyperkalemia and hyponatremia, common laboratory findings in CAH. The most appropriate next step in management is hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone therapy to replace the cortisol and aldosterone deficiency due to the CAH. Estrogen replacement therapy, dexamethasone therapy, and spironolactone therapy are not appropriate in the management of CAH in a newborn.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The newborn has clitoromegaly and laboratory results showing hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and an acid-base imbalance, which are suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia. Hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone therapy is the appropriate next step in management. Estrogen replacement therapy is not indicated in newborns, and dexamethasone and spironolactone are not the first-line treatments for congenital adrenal hyperplasia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Clitoromegaly in newborn girls suggests congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), which can be caused by deficiency of 21-hydroxylase enzyme. The laboratory results show elevated potassium, decreased sodium, and metabolic acidosis, which are consistent with CAH. Hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone therapy are the appropriate treatments for CAH. Estrogen replacement therapy is not indicated in newborns, and dexamethasone and spironolactone would not address the underlying cause of CAH.
